data.title: 'twould be nice if passing a line number as an argument to atom were possible
data.body:
Currently I'm doing something like the following to open the source file for a method in dotcom (and Ruby-land, for that matter). 

``` ruby
irb(main):028:0> module Kernel
irb(main):029:1>   def atom(meth)
irb(main):030:2>     src = self.method(meth).source_location
irb(main):031:2>     `open -a atom #{src[0]}`
irb(main):032:2>   end
irb(main):033:1> end
irb(main):034:0> u.atom(:languages)
```

Works great!

But it would be even sweeter if atom let me pass along the line number as an argument so I could go right to the method in question!

data.title: Namespace theme styles by adding a class to the body
data.body:
Packages should specify the styles for each theme they care to support. I'm sure you guys have talked about how you might want to do this. This is a simple way.

It just adds a class of the theme name to the body element. 

So in my package, I can specify a 

```
.atom-dark-ui {
   .my-plugin-junk {...}
}
```

We could also encourage that they are broken up into stylesheets named by the theme. But of course, a package author could just put this theme specific stuff into their global stylesheet. 

An alternative is selectively loading stylesheets with the same name as the theme from the package's `stylesheet` directory (I remember a section in the docs talking about this with a 'not implemented' tag). I haven't looked too deeply into the pkg manager yet to know how difficult it might be.

Thoughts?

data.title: Multiple Lines Paste as One in Soft Wrap Mode
data.body:
I pasted in some text from Wikipedia:

```
irection[edit source | editbeta]
Intelligence requirements are determined by a decision maker to meet his/her objectives. In the Federal government of the United States, requirements can be issued from the White House or the Congress. In NATO, a commander uses requirements (sometimes called 'Essential Elements of Intelligence (EEIs)) to initiate the intelligence cycle.
Collection[edit source | editbeta]
In response to requirements, an intelligence staff develops an intelligence collection plan applying available sources and methods and seeking intelligence from other agencies. Depending on the organization and its access, sources may include HUMINT (human intelligence), IMINT (imagery intelligence), ELINT (electronic intelligence), SIGINT (Signals Intelligence), OSINT (open source, or publicly available intelligence), etc.
Processing[edit source | editbeta]
Once the collection plan is executed and information arrives, it is processed for exploitation. This involves the translation of raw intelligence materials from a foreign language, evaluation of relevance and reliability, and collation of the raw intelligence in preparation for exploitation.
Analysis[edit source | editbeta]
Analysis establishes the significance and implications of processed intelligence, integrates it by combining disparate pieces of information to identify collateral information and patterns, then interprets the significance of any newly developed knowledge.
Dissemination[edit source | editbeta]
Finished intelligence products take many forms depending on the needs of the decision maker and reporting requirements. The level of urgency of various types of intelligence is typically established by an intelligence organization or community. An indications and warning (I&W) bulletin would require higher precedence than an annual report, for example.
Feedback[edit source | editbeta]
The intelligence cycle is a closed loop; feedback is received from the decision maker and revised requirements issued.
```

into the editor while soft wrap was enabled (it makes it easier to write prose). When I did I got a weird visual bug at line 17+:
![screen shot 2013-08-10 at 8 08 25 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/44774/942505/dd29bf8c-01b7-11e3-819a-051fecc55166.png)

When I toggled soft wrap it went away, but it was at first a pretty jarring visual bug.

data.title: jsncostello's wish list
data.body:
There is one feature in Sublime Text 2 that I often use and it really makes my day. It has the option to save all of your open tabs and window setup as a 'Project'. This really comes in handy as a designer working on applications that have multiple views and scss files. It saves the project as 'project name.sublime-project. That way if I have to quickly change gears to work different files, I can easily return to a complex project with one action. 

Also, consider adding functions/actions or default key commands to appropriate file menus in the application bar. I feel it would dramatically help feature/function discoverability. A lot of designers won't have experience with Vim, etc and may want to start with Atom as it is, out of the box before customizing keybindings.

I am really looking forward to moving over to Atom full-time and send mad props to your team. It's amazing to witness Atom coming to life.

data.title: Soft wrapping breaks and duplicates lines in certain situations
data.body:
Soft wrapping breaks apart completely and creates a big mess if a certain sequence of actions is performed. I'm on OSX 10.8.4 and Atom 17.0.

To reproduce:
1. Start Atom, open a blank new file, and turn on soft wrapping
2. Enter text until it wraps to the other line:
   ![screen shot 2013-08-07 at 3 27 54 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/928220/9fc0a024-ffb0-11e2-9a71-ff8e5c034dcc.png)
3. Your cursor being at the end of line 1, press ENTER to go to the next line. This correctly creates a newline character and moves the cursor to the beginning of the next line:
   ![screen shot 2013-08-07 at 3 29 19 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/928227/d228929c-ffb0-11e2-9cbf-d1a0742f17d9.png)
4. Press BACKSPACE. This deletes the new line that was just created and correctly moves the cursor back to the end of line 1. Screenshot same as in step 2:
   ![screen shot 2013-08-07 at 3 27 54 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/928287/04a372d6-ffb2-11e2-8c08-82801985b4ef.png)
5. Press ENTER again, as if to repeat step 3. This messes everything up:
   ![screen shot 2013-08-07 at 3 30 13 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/38924/928234/ef9865c8-ffb0-11e2-94c3-db980f90c8c4.png)

So, the first "virtual" line was duplicated. Also, this duplicated first line is now non-selectable and non-editable -- I can't even put my cursor there (it's frozen). 

DevTools console doesn't show any errors.

data.title: Zombie Buffer in buffer list
data.body:
If you delete a file and Atom has serialized the path into it's buffer list there isn't a way to remove the file from that list which can be annoying.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open and save file1 and file 2
2. Switch back to file1
3. Close atom
4. Delete file2
5. Open atom
6. Attempt to use the buffer list to navigate to file2
7. Receive an error indicate the file no longer exists.

Expected behavior:
- Allow you to open a non-existent file
- Or automatically remove the buffer from the list

Possibly related to #679

data.title: Reconsider use of "meta"
data.body:
There is no "meta" button on my keyboard. I've always disliked meta in Emacs and think it's a bigger mistake in Atom due to the social nature. Having to use "meta" when talking about Atom but "command" when talking about other applications during the same conversation is awkward. On top of that, having to mentally translate "meta" to "command" in Atom in keymaps or text is annoying.

I would much rather we do what github.com and Sublime do. When possible do user-agent sniffing, when not just list out both options.

http://www.sublimetext.com/ on OS X:

> Use Multiple Selections to rename variables quickly.
> Here ⌘D is used to select the next occurrence of the current word.

Windows:

> Use Multiple Selections to rename variables quickly.
> Here Ctrl+D is used to select the next occurrence of the current word.

On GitHub hit `?` to see this same thing in action.

In Sublime's [static docs](http://www.sublimetext.com/docs/2/multiple_selection_with_the_keyboard.html) they list both:

> To add the line above or below to the selection, use Ctl+Alt+Up and Ctrl+Alt+down (OS X: Ctrl+Shift+Up and Ctrl+Shift+Down).

And in GitHub's help docs we offer Mac and Windows versions when there is variation between them:

https://help.github.com/articles/working-with-ssh-key-passphrases

Edit: Also wanted to add that stuff like #328 isn't going to be 100% fixed with documentation. I guarantee people will be confused the first time they use Atom. Not a great first run experience.

data.title: Add ability to query for a range covering a given scope/position
data.body:
Ready to merge. Fire at will.

@jasonrudolph and I worked on a lot of this at summit. We built out a toggle-quotes feature and wanted to be able to find the range of a string containing the cursor's current position. I'd like to replace the arrays of simple tokens in `TokenizedBuffer` with a proper concrete syntax tree, with the tokens as its leaves. But for now I just scan left and right on the current line to find the limits of the scope. Definitely worth revisiting.
